item.title: Remember, remember
item.description: Political scientists have often wondered how to reconcile two basic facts: Many voters struggle to recall basic information, like the names of prominent politicians or their most well-known policy positions Many voters manage to vote “correctly” - that is, they vote for the candidate that most closely aligns with their stated preferences How do they do it? There are two basic models of how voters process information: memory-based processing and the online tally.

item.title: Hokus focus (group)
item.description: Arguments in favour of the usefulness of focus groups: They tell us things that pollsters might miss I’ve always been puzzled by this argument. Most standard political surveys include at least one question that is either open-ended or allows for a very wide range of responses - typically a question about the “most important issue” facing the country. In general, I’d be more persuaded if proponents of this argument could actually point to an example of an insight gleaned from a focus group that wasn’t evident from existing surveys.

item.title: Getting fit
item.description: “Labour economic policies are popular, so why aren’t Labour?” As this analysis from YouGov suggests, Labour’s policy proposals were popular when taken one-by-one, but when voters step back and evaluate which party would do best on the economy overall, Labour is at a severe disadvantage. Voters were twice as likely to pick Boris Johnson (34%) over Jeremy Corbyn (16%), when asked who they trusted most to run the economy.

item.title: Slogun to the head
item.description: “Get Brexit Done.” Those were “the three words that helped Boris Johnson win” Britain’s 2019 election, according to Time Magazine. The slogan was a “golden key” that unlocked a Conservative victory, says the Telegraph. Not to be outdone, a Spectactor columnist wrote that it was a “work of political genius”, with “power, more power than us smug, clever types who obsess about details and facts naturally recognise”. Even prominent Labour figures like John McDonnell said that the slogan had “successfully resonated” with voters.
